results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Netherlands, Switzerland and Wales, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:40:00 sign “The Dingle” of the Dingle Gardens
00:01:14:00 folk dancing at a country fair
00:02:10:00 horse jumping
00:02:51:00 Dutch seaside featuring people in lounge chairs
00:03:15:00 canal trip through countryside and urban area
00:04:11:00 farm life and creatures including a white peacock, and a young adult in fashionable clothing and clogs holding a skull
00:05:55:00 Commonwealth War Grave sign and cemetery
00:06:05:00 Spannenburg sign shot from a car
00:06:30:00 De Dude Are Museum sign and building shot from boat on a canal
00:07:29:00 in city, people gathering for the arrival of a celebrity
00:07:46:00 three people lining up to eat fish by holding tail up in the air above their heads, in sync
00:07:52:00 miniature theme park featuring tiny windmills, trams, boats, gardens, with one of the boats on fire
00:11:46:00 local market in Rotterdam, possibly; youth fashion
00:14:03:00 bus trip to Switzerland, featuring mountains and countryside scenes
00:16:02:00 feeding bears in a zoo
00:18:09:00 scene of large waterfall
00:20:13:00 Sinclair’s friends having a snowball fight
00:20:58:00 steam train

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

Short film of wedding reception of David Rowe. Relates to B2003514. Also features the Lae War cemetery, which features on B2003516.

Selected Highlights List from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens at Lae War Cemetary
00:00:45:00 local New Guinea football/rugby team play a match
00:01:23:00 wedding ceremony outdoors

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This is a very short film, featuring graduating students posing with certificates from Goroka Technical College, Margot Gillian, Chapel and opening of the Development Bank at Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:01:07:00 opening of Development Bank, Goroka
00:01:43:00 local group perform ceremony in traditional dress to celebrate opening of bank
00:02:11:00 amazing mouth pieces worn by First Peoples as part of their ceremonial dress, procession

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This very short film contains footage of mountains on the way to Lae, New Guinea. It relates to reel B2003518.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This very short film features a Goroka Technical College students’ graduation ceremony (renamed University of Goroka, possibly Goroka Teachers College). Many students in western graduation robes, some in traditional dress.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:01:20:00 two elders play wind pipes in honour or to welcome students

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a wedding in Goroka, featuring Evelyn Sinclair and friends. The happy couple take off in an airplane for their honeymoon. Relates to reel B2003518.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan) 00:00:00:00 guests at wedding
00:00:25:00 wedding car decorated
00:00:28:00 happy couple cutting the wedding cake
00:01:01:00 bride and groom posing in front of plane; ‘Just Hitched’ sprayed onto the front of the plane
00:01:25:00 happy couple takes off in airplane

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:02:47:00 changing of the Guard
00:05:23:00 Stonehenge – brief look at Stonehenge
00:05:34:00 Stratford-Upon-Avon Cricket Club sign, walking through gardens and a spot of cricket
00:06:58:00 Shakespeare’s Birthplace Trust
00:09:17:00 road trip sign to Penrith, Carlisle and Kendal
00:10:17:00 Fferry trip – Windemere ferry, ’The Ferry House Windemere Laboratory of the Freshwater Biological Association Private Gardens’
00:13:15:00 Loch Lomond Sailings Ltd
00:14:42:00 the Elizabethan Inn – filmmaker and wife meet up with three other women at the inn
00:15:39:00 Tormore Distillery with friends – Long John Scotch Whiskey
00:16:56:00 father and two young girls feeding ducks at a lake
00:17:41:00 Roths Glen Hotel – mini donkeys and friends
00:19:11:00 sign to Pitlochry
00:19:45:00 castle or Military Fort in Edinburgh, guards in kilts
00:20:17:00 cemetery for soldier dogs
00:21:14:00 Blackpool

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
This film is a continuation from Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7

This film begins with the introduction of the Baining people. The Baining people are the original inhabitants of the Gazelle Peninsula of East New Britain. According to Albert Drayton the people had just been brought out from the mountains as part of the missionary work.

Numerous ceremonies are seen in this film including a wedding, dances, spear throwing and a mock battle.

The later part of the film is the return to Australia briefly visiting Brisbane and Sydney before returning to Melbourne.

Both deck quoits and deck tennis are seen being played on the ship.

There are scenes of the Sydney Harbour bridge, the Sydney Railway station and Town hall.

The film finishes with the Drayton family in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 – Missionary Grounds and local huts

00:00:31:00 – Footage of the Baining people with women weaving thread and stocking the fire

00:01:08:00 – Performances for the tourists including a marriage ceremony, Tower dance and spear throwing, a ceremonial dance, a mock battle and a victory dance

00:06:05:00 – Mt Drayton with one of the chiefs

00:06:09:00 – Performance with men wearing large decorative head gear supported with string controlled by the women

00:07:23:00 – Baining man with baby

00:07:36:00 – Masks and head pieces being given as a gift to the missionary cruise

00:08:15:00 – Cruise passengers packed into the ship deck on journey back from Papua New Guinea

00:08:48:00 – Cruise Passengers with the ship’s captain and Mr Dennis, the mayor of Northcote, Melbourne

00:09:18:00 – Passengers playing Quoits on the deck of the ship

00:10:11:00 – Views of Sydney Harbour Bridge with Harold Drayton and an Electric Train

00:10:45:00 – Sydney Central Railway Station and Town Hall with street view of traffic officer directing traffic

00:11:34:00 – Mavis, unidentified woman and Mrs Drayton

00:12:36:00 – Drayton family and passengers playing Deck Quoits and Tennis

00:13:26:00 – Albert Drayton and mother unpacking the car at Hampshire Road, Melbourne

00:13:35:00 - Mavis, unknown, Harold, Roy, Albert, unknown, Mrs Drayton (mother)

00:13:45:00 – Members of the Drayton family posing with gifts including Roy, Harold, Albert, Ted Drayton and Mother

00:14:34:00 – Peter (Mavis’s son) crawling to his aeroplane

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film follows on from the Drayton Family Movies: Reel 5

The film continues exploring events and scenes from Raboul in Papua New Guinea then continues to other villages.

There are many scenes of local people in costume providing performances and ceremonies for the tourists of the cruise ship.

There are a few scenes of missionary buildings and schools and many scenes of students in uniform. The student marching teams are seen doing regimented marching exercises.

Also seen are ruins and gravestones from early missionaries on the island.

Towards the end of the film a duk-duk dance is filmed. At the time it was an illegal dance to perform.

The film finishes at the arrival of another village in New Britain.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Young Chinese students, at the Overseas Chinese School, Raboul

00:00:09:00 – Harold Drayton, Mr Jefferies, Albert Drayton standing in a church doorway, Raboul

00:00:29:00 – Local Cemetery holding Australians soldiers killed in the First World War, Raboul

00:01:12:00 – Guards on Duty, Government House, Raboul

00:01:41:00 – Prisoners marching back to their cells after a day’s work, Raboul

00:01:51:00 – local costume and dance performance. George Brown College, Raboul

00:02:57:00 – College Boys in uniform marching, Raboul

results.description:
This film follows on from the Drayton Family Movies: Reel 5

The film continues exploring events and scenes from Raboul in Papua New Guinea then continues to other villages.

There are many scenes of local people in costume providing performances and ceremonies for the tourists of the cruise ship.

There are a few scenes of missionary buildings and schools and many scenes of students in uniform. The student marching teams are seen doing regimented marching exercises.

Also seen are ruins and gravestones from early missionaries on the island.

Towards the end of the film a duk-duk dance is filmed. At the time it was an illegal dance to perform.

The film finishes at the arrival of another village in New Britain.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Young Chinese students, at the Overseas Chinese School, Raboul

00:00:09:00 – Harold Drayton, Mr Jefferies, Albert Drayton standing in a church doorway, Raboul

00:00:29:00 – Local Cemetery holding Australians soldiers killed in the First World War, Raboul

00:01:12:00 – Guards on Duty, Government House, Raboul

00:01:41:00 – Prisoners marching back to their cells after a day’s work, Raboul

00:01:51:00 – local costume and dance performance. George Brown College, Raboul

00:02:57:00 – College Boys in uniform marching, Raboul

00:03:22:00 – Harold Drayton, Mrs Drayton, Mr Drayton, Mrs Lowe, Mrs Hargraves part of the Sunshine cruise passengers drinking from coconuts

00:03:56:00 – Dance Performances and music, St George Browns College, Raboul

00:07:03:00 – George Brown College boys and girls, performing marching exercises, rhythm exercises with coconut shells and sticks, Raboul
